events.originalText: Agents with the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement raided a slaughterhouse in Tennessee, detaining nearly 100 Hispanic workers in one of the largest immigration raids in the history of the U.S.
events.subtitle: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement
events.headline: ICE agents detain nearly 100 Hispanic workers in Tennessee raid

events.originalText: An explosion at a coal mine in West Virginia killed 29 miners in the United States' worst mining disaster in 40 years.
events.subtitle: Coal mining
events.headline: 29 miners killed in West Virginia coal mine explosion

events.originalText: The North Korean satellite Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2 was launched from the Tonghae Satellite Launching Ground and passed over Japan, sparking concerns it may have been a trial run of technology that could be used to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles.
events.subtitle: Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2
events.headline: North Korean satellite launched over Japan raises concerns

events.originalText: Fan violence broke out before a UEFA Cup semi-final in Istanbul, Turkey, resulting in two Leeds United supporters being stabbed to death and Galatasaray supporters being banned from attending the second leg in England.
events.subtitle: 2000 UEFA Cup semi-final violence
events.headline: Fan violence erupts in Istanbul before UEFA Cup semi-final

events.originalText: The Akashi Kaikyo Bridge (pictured), then the world's longest suspension bridge, linking Awaji Island and Kobe in Japan, opened to traffic.
events.subtitle: Akashi Kaikyo Bridge
events.headline: Akashi Kaikyo Bridge opens in Japan, world's longest suspension bridge

events.originalText: The Libyan secret service bombed a discotheque in West Berlin, resulting in three deaths and 229 others injured.
events.subtitle: West Berlin discotheque bombing
events.headline: Libyan secret service bombs discotheque in West Berlin

events.originalText: During the Buddhist Uprising, South Vietnamese military prime minister Nguyễn Cao Kỳ personally attempted to lead the capture of the restive city of Đà Nẵng before backing down.
events.subtitle: Buddhist Uprising
events.headline: South Vietnamese military prime minister attempts to capture Đà Nẵng

events.originalText: Aware that he was slowing down both physically and mentally in his old age, Winston Churchill retired as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
events.subtitle: Winston Churchill
events.headline: Winston Churchill retires as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom

events.originalText: Siegfried Lederer, a Czech Jew, escaped from Auschwitz with the aid of an SS officer who opposed the Holocaust.
events.subtitle: History of the Jews in the Czech lands
events.headline: Czech Jew escapes Auschwitz with SS officer's help

events.originalText: An F5 tornado struck Tupelo, Mississippi, killing at least 216 people during one of the deadliest tornado outbreaks in U.S. history.
events.subtitle: Fujita scale
events.headline: F5 tornado strikes Tupelo, Mississippi, killing at least 216

events.originalText: A spectator stand collapsed (pictured) during a Scotland–England football match at Ibrox Park, Govan, killing 25 supporters and injuring more than 500 others.
events.subtitle: 1902 Ibrox disaster
events.headline: Spectator stand collapses during Scotland-England football match, 25 killed

events.originalText: Birkenhead Park, generally acknowledged as the world's first publicly funded civic park, opened in Birkenhead, England.
events.subtitle: Birkenhead Park
events.headline: Birkenhead Park opens in England, world's first publicly funded civic park

events.originalText: The Statute of Anne, the first legislation in Great Britain providing for copyright regulated by the government and courts, received royal assent and entered into force five days later.
events.subtitle: Statute of Anne
events.headline: Statute of Anne receives royal assent in Great Britain

events.originalText: Native American Pocahontas married English colonist John Rolfe, leading to a period of peace between the Powhatan people and the inhabitants of Jamestown, Virginia.
events.subtitle: Native Americans in the United States
events.headline: Pocahontas marries John Rolfe, leading to peace in Jamestown

events.originalText: The Fatimid Caliphate began a second unsuccessful invasion of Egypt, then under Abbasid rule.
events.subtitle: Fatimid Caliphate
events.headline: Fatimid Caliphate begins second unsuccessful invasion of Egypt
